services.title: GreeniTwinCity
services.description: The 3D City Models of Bengreurir, also known as the cityâ€™s digital twin, are a virtual rendering of the cityâ€™s environment, operations and changing circumstances. The digital twin is a combination of information technology services, open data and constantly updating information.

services.title: The GreenCity of Bengreurir
services.description: The Green City of Benguerir, also known as the Mohammed VI Green City, is an innovative urban project in Morocco that focuses on sustainability and ecological living. Built around the Mohammed VI Polytechnic University, it aims to establish a leading smart and ecological knowledge city, offering residents a modern and attractive living environment.

services.title: Eco-Friendly Transportation
services.description: With the vision of transforming the City of Bengueruerir into a much greener, more serene, and more active city, the   GreenItwinCity project was proposed by the TOP. Green City will be pedestrianized to fulfill different improvement criteria across the city to insure conditions for eco-friendly transportation.

accordion1.title: What is the Urban Model ?
accordion1.desc: It is a 3D model of the city, rich in semantic information about urban objects, including buildings. This model allows us to visualize the properties of each building such as the year of construction, number of floors, and urban zoning area. Additionally, it incorporates other urban elements such as vegetation, water resources, mobility networks, and terrain. This provides an in-depth view of the urban fabric's structuring.

accordion1.title: How was the urban data model made ?
accordion1.desc: The Urban data model is constructed upon a rich tapestry of city maps, geographic data, registers, and aerial photography, alongside detailed building data models. Its methodology involves precisely situating buildings within the urban landscape by translating building footprints from the Bengreurir City Plan onto the terrain model. This integration yields three-dimensional structures, merging terrain and surface models to accurately depict buildings' walls and roofs.Presently, the data model showcases buildings, terrain features, and waterways. However, future iterations will incorporate additional elements such as trees and urban furniture objects.

accordion1.title: How can the Urban model be used ?
